content.raw:
It looks like when `math.hh` is generated, it puts the `math/detail/Cylinder.hh` file above the `math/Cylinder.hh` file.

I think that the best fix would be to not include the detail files in the `math.hh` header, as they are included at the bottom of each of their respective headers.  This would probably mean making a change to the way that `ign_install_all_headers` would work.

I had to revert the `EXCLUDE_DIRS` [7d7e53d](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/commits/7d7e53da38c147b64a12e91fbda82140451779ec?at=default) because it prevent the `details/*` files from being installed.

The header guards in the `details/*.hh` will prevent them from being included twice.

I would classify ign-common as being in error as well. While it doesn’t break anything, including the “detail” in the auto-generated header file is not the best thing to do. It’s only for aesthetic reasons.

content.raw:
I think this pattern came from @mxgrey as it's also used in dartsim:

* https://github.com/dartsim/dart/blob/master/dart/math/ConfigurationSpace.hpp#L139
* https://github.com/dartsim/dart/blob/master/dart/math/detail/ConfigurationSpace.hpp#L36
content.html:
I think this pattern came from @mxgrey as it's also used in dartsim:

  • https://github.com/dartsim/dart/blob/master/dart/math/ConfigurationSpace.hpp#L139
  • https://github.com/dartsim/dart/blob/master/dart/math/detail/ConfigurationSpace.hpp#L36

It’s not an error; it’s very much intentional, and it works as intended. An explanation:

Suppose you have headers A.hh and B.hh, and these two headers are intended to work together, such that if one of them gets included, the other one needs to be included as well, and in a particular order, like

#include <A.hh>
#include <B.hh>

You don’t want to force the user to know that both files need to be included in this particular order. You also want to be robust to the scenario that the user includes both of them in the wrong order, e.g.

#include <B.hh>
#include <A.hh>

because the user might not know any better.

The solution to this is to put the line #include <B.hh> at the bottom of A.hh, while putting #include <A.hh> at the top of B.hh.

This ensures that whether the user includes either A.hh or B.hh or if the user includes both in the wrong order (basically, no matter how a user might try to cram these headers into their translation unit) the order in which the include directives get expanded will produce the desired result.

content.raw: That makes sense in the generic case. However, I have been operating on the belief that a user should never directly include a header file from the details subdirectory. The details subdirectory exists to hide \(sort-of\) & organize implementation details. If we break the circular include, then a user is forced to the use “correct” header file.
content.html: That makes sense in the generic case. However, I have been operating on the belief that a user should never directly include a header file from the details subdirectory. The details subdirectory exists to hide (sort-of) & organize implementation details. If we break the circular include, then a user is forced to the use “correct” header file.

content.raw:
To be exact, this isn’t a circular dependency. Instead, it’s a linear dependency with a strict ordering requirement.

You’re absolutely right that we don’t *want* users to include detail headers directly in their user code, but we can't really stop them from doing that without sabotaging them with compiler errors that can be very difficult to understand. And in this case, leaving the `#include` out of the detail header won’t force a user to avoid including the detail header; it’ll just *sometimes* \(but not always\) create cryptic compilation errors, depending on how exactly the user decided to include the detail header.

But more importantly, this strategy of including headers exactly where they’re needed also helps us to avoid internal mixups within our own code. If we don’t make the inclusion ordering air-tight, then we may run into situations where certain combinations or orderings of public API headers will result in unintended compilation errors for end-users, like what happened in this case with the auto-generated master header.
content.html:
To be exact, this isn’t a circular dependency. Instead, it’s a linear dependency with a strict ordering requirement.

You’re absolutely right that we don’t want users to include detail headers directly in their user code, but we can't really stop them from doing that without sabotaging them with compiler errors that can be very difficult to understand. And in this case, leaving the #include out of the detail header won’t force a user to avoid including the detail header; it’ll just sometimes (but not always) create cryptic compilation errors, depending on how exactly the user decided to include the detail header.

But more importantly, this strategy of including headers exactly where they’re needed also helps us to avoid internal mixups within our own code. If we don’t make the inclusion ordering air-tight, then we may run into situations where certain combinations or orderings of public API headers will result in unintended compilation errors for end-users, like what happened in this case with the auto-generated master header.

content.raw: In short: I would recommend we try to make guarantees \(whenever possible\) that our code will keep itself correct instead of relying on the user to know how to use it correctly.
content.html: In short: I would recommend we try to make guarantees (whenever possible) that our code will keep itself correct instead of relying on the user to know how to use it correctly.

content.raw:
As far as I can tell it is a circular dependency. The header guards prevent the compiler from doing bad things, but there are two header files that include each other. I’m making a big deal out of this because it rubs my undergrad computer science bones in all the wrong ways.

I’d like a user to receive a compiler error if they do something wrong, but I can live with header files including each other. However,  I don’t want to advertise the “details/\*” files in the auto-generated header file.
content.html:
As far as I can tell it is a circular dependency. The header guards prevent the compiler from doing bad things, but there are two header files that include each other. I’m making a big deal out of this because it rubs my undergrad computer science bones in all the wrong ways.

I’d like a user to receive a compiler error if they do something wrong, but I can live with header files including each other. However, I don’t want to advertise the “details/*” files in the auto-generated header file.

content.raw:
> However, I don’t want to advertise the “details/\*” files in the auto-generated header file.  

I'm totally on board with that, and it makes sense to make that a "policy" for all ignition libraries, so I would advocate that we make a PR to `ign-cmake` to make that the standard behavior.

> As far as I can tell it is a circular dependency  

Strictly speaking, a "circular dependency" between `A.hh` and `B.hh` means that the body of `A.hh` is required to come before the body of `B.hh` and simultaneously the body of `B.hh` is required to come before the body of `A.hh` \(where "body" refers to all the content of a header, ignoring its `#include` directives\). This is logically impossible, and will always result in a compilation error. Whenever this happens, it means that there is a design error in the code, which usually needs to be solved using forward declarations \(or sometimes fancier techniques\).

What we have in our situation is that the body of `A.hh` is required to come before the body of `B.hh` and simultaneously the body of `B.hh` is required to come **after** the body of `A.hh`. There is no logical contradiction here; it’s just not a very common situation for headers in C/C\+\+, because usually the body of a header does not strictly require the body of any other header to come after it.

Remember that the location of an `#include` directive within a header matters. The text from the header is effectively copy/pasted at the exact location of the `#include` directive \(although anything blocked by an `#ifdef` will effectively be left out, which is how header guards do their thing\). If you think carefully about how `#include` directives get expanded, you'll find that `A.hh` and `B.hh` will always do the right thing if `A.hh` includes `B.hh` at its bottom while `B.hh` includes `A.hh` at its top.

The pattern is also well-tested in DART where it’s been in use for at least 3 years without any issues. It’s not a common pattern, because most well-known template libraries \(e.g. Boost, STL, Eigen\) don’t bother to split template declarations and implementations into separate files. But I think that’s a big part of why those libraries feel so unapproachable to beginners: It’s easy to get overwhelmed and scared away by template syntax, and it’s hard to find the information that you actually care about \(which is usually just the signature of a class or function\).
content.html:
However, I don’t want to advertise the “details/*” files in the auto-generated header file.

I'm totally on board with that, and it makes sense to make that a "policy" for all ignition libraries, so I would advocate that we make a PR to ign-cmake to make that the standard behavior.

As far as I can tell it is a circular dependency

Strictly speaking, a "circular dependency" between A.hh and B.hh means that the body of A.hh is required to come before the body of B.hh and simultaneously the body of B.hh is required to come before the body of A.hh (where "body" refers to all the content of a header, ignoring its #include directives). This is logically impossible, and will always result in a compilation error. Whenever this happens, it means that there is a design error in the code, which usually needs to be solved using forward declarations (or sometimes fancier techniques).

What we have in our situation is that the body of A.hh is required to come before the body of B.hh and simultaneously the body of B.hh is required to come after the body of A.hh. There is no logical contradiction here; it’s just not a very common situation for headers in C/C++, because usually the body of a header does not strictly require the body of any other header to come after it.

Remember that the location of an #include directive within a header matters. The text from the header is effectively copy/pasted at the exact location of the #include directive (although anything blocked by an #ifdef will effectively be left out, which is how header guards do their thing). If you think carefully about how #include directives get expanded, you'll find that A.hh and B.hh will always do the right thing if A.hh includes B.hh at its bottom while B.hh includes A.hh at its top.

The pattern is also well-tested in DART where it’s been in use for at least 3 years without any issues. It’s not a common pattern, because most well-known template libraries (e.g. Boost, STL, Eigen) don’t bother to split template declarations and implementations into separate files. But I think that’s a big part of why those libraries feel so unapproachable to beginners: It’s easy to get overwhelmed and scared away by template syntax, and it’s hard to find the information that you actually care about (which is usually just the signature of a class or function).

content.raw:
Sorry I'm late to this. Just thought I'd mention that bullet has separate classes for cylinders oriented along different axes:

* y-axis: [btCylinderShape](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/blob/master/src/BulletCollision/CollisionShapes/btCylinderShape.h#L23)
* x-axis: [btCylinderShapeX](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/blob/master/src/BulletCollision/CollisionShapes/btCylinderShape.h#L137)
* z-axis: [btCylinderShapeZ](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/blob/master/src/BulletCollision/CollisionShapes/btCylinderShape.h#L160)
content.html:
Sorry I'm late to this. Just thought I'd mention that bullet has separate classes for cylinders oriented along different axes:

  • y-axis: btCylinderShape
  • x-axis: btCylinderShapeX
  • z-axis: btCylinderShapeZ

content.raw:
Without having looked at the code, I assume the separate classes in bullet
are for collision detection performance. Do you know if there is something
related to inertia and material properties that we should be aware of?
content.html: Without having looked at the code, I assume the separate classes in bullet are for collision detection performance. Do you know if there is something related to inertia and material properties that we should be aware of?

content.raw: It could also be to disambiguate the axis of the cylinder, while also allowing users to choose their preferred axis without needing to add a rotation.
content.html: It could also be to disambiguate the axis of the cylinder, while also allowing users to choose their preferred axis without needing to add a rotation.
